subject: Re: [junit] Why is it considered an error if there is no test in the file?
msgSnippet: Hi Joseph, I m assuming that you want to do this with jUnit 4.0 since 3.x requires you to extend TestCase. Disclaimer: I m not very experienced with JUnit 4.x
messageBody:
Hi Joseph,

I'm assuming that you want to do this with jUnit 4.0 since 3.x
requires you to extend TestCase.

Disclaimer: I'm not very experienced with JUnit 4.x so there may be
possibilities there that I'm not aware of.

That is a bit of an unusual aproach and I don't think it is supported.
If I would want to do what you want to do I would do something similar
to what we did in dynamic test suite in rMock:
http://rmock.sourceforge.net/dynamicsuites.html

The benefit with examining your classes to descide what should go into
your test suite is that it gives you access to information such as
implemented interfaces, annotations etc while in ant you can only
descide based on file-name and location.

So I guess I'm saying that instead of trying to work around treating a
class that does not contain any tests like an error try to find a way
to include only those classes that do contain tests to the runner. I
think you may be more successful with that.

In general I thik that jUnit is designed with a certain process in
mind while TestNG is more flexible in that sense. It may very well
happen that you find that testNG suits your needs better.

Now that I tried to answer your question I am curious, wouldn't having
your test methods sprinkled all over your code constrain you
unneccesarily? I'm thinking that you would probably need to provide
default constructors in those classes that contian tests in order to
be able to run them for instance.

Wouldn't it become confusing for someone looking at the code later.
Wouldn't it be harder to see what has to do with testing and what has
to do with passing the tests?

Don't get me wrong, try it by all means, I just saw those potential drawbacks.
Take care!
/Joakim Ohlrogge

> From the faq the pattern everyone else seems to be using is that their
> tests are in a seperate java file from their code. I'd like to
> spinkle test methods throughout my code, so the test can be right next
> to the code it is testing. I'd like to create a junit ant task that
> just runs on my whole codebase, but not all of my classes will have
> test methods and I'll get an error for each class that doesn't (and I
> don't want to have to explictily add each class to my build.xml file
> when I add a test). So how do I tell junit that it isn't an error if
> a class does not have a test method?
>
